author: Abc Radio Canberra
title: Muni: The ups and downs of mountain unicycling - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: ACT 
As if riding a unicycle wasn't hard enough, try riding one up and down a mountain. 
That is exactly what 67-year-old John Evershed is "addicted" to doing when he finishes a day of work at his IT job. 
"Some people go to a gym and sit on a bike that does nothing and they get some exercise, and then they couldn't be bothered to go next week," he said. 
"Whereas I've got this thing where I get exercise, I focus all the time because any moment you could fall off it. 
"It's just a heap of fun and I just keep learning and learning and learning." 
Mr Evershed is a member of the ACT Unicycle Riders Society which regularly meets at Mount Stromlo to do muni (mountain unicycling). 
Some unicycles come with a brake under the seat, but not the one Mr Evershed rides. 
"It's relatively safe, although every time I go out I fall off several times," he said. 
"You can fall off and run off in front of it most of the time and it bounces and skittles its way over to the side and you pick it up and start again." 'Safer' cycling downhill on one wheel 
Karl Denton, 42, said cycling downhill was safer on one wheel than two. 
"When you're going downhill on a bike you're actually facing forward, you're facing downhill, whereas on a unicycle you're still pretty much vertical," he said. 
"So if that bike stops, you're going to get thrown over the handlebars, you're going to land on your shoulder or your arm or whatever. 
"Whereas on a unicycle if you don't like how it's going you can just jump off the back or you can put your foot off to the side and pretty much step off it." 
But learning to ride a unicycle can be much harder than riding a bicycle. Steep learning curve 
Rob Armstrong took up mountain unicycling in 2008 after spending years mountain biking. 
"It's really hard for beginners because you've got this steep, hard learning curve and the other riders of course are just riding along happily," he said. 
Mr Armstrong said mounting a unicycle was the hardest part. 
"If you get it wrong, you fall off and you have to do it again. 
"The more tired you get the more you fall off; it's rinse and repeat, and it just gets very, very tiring and very, very frustrating very quickly." 
But mastering the unicycle appears to be worth the effort. 
"You could almost say it's addictive," Mr Evershed said.
